code: import React from'react';import"./singleBlog1.css";import{jsx as _jsx}from"react/jsx-runtime";import{jsxs as _jsxs}from"react/jsx-runtime";export default function Blog4(){return/*#__PURE__*/_jsxs("div",{id:"top",className:"Blog4",children:[/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("h2",{children:"A critical analysis of the internet artwork JODI and its relevance in the world of digital art"}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"What is art? Art and what exactly it is has always been quite a controversial topic in history and contemporary philosophy. Even the idea of whether art can be defined is itself a rather controversial topic. According to the Oxford Dictionary, art is the expression or application of human creative skill and imagination, typically in a visual form such as painting or sculpture, producing works to be appreciated primarily for their beauty or emotional power [1]. Art was always constrained to the mediums of pen, paper and the physical environment and so its definitions were formed to those constraints. Today we live in a digital world, with digital constraints and because of that I believe we need to redefine art, move it away from a standard of beauty, authenticity and audience. The constraints of art in a digital age are dissolved, the definition is far more fluid and needs to be examined in further detail."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"The French artist Edgar Degas says \u201CArt is not what you see, but what you make others see.\u201D I believe this quote quite accurately sums up all great art, or at least the purpose of all great artworks, regardless of their medium. Art has the power to influence, and with this power it can sometimes affect real change. An example of this is Leonardo Da Vinci's studies of the foetus in the womb. Da Vinci's discoveries and methods went on to change the way that both artists and scientists studied the human body [2]. In order to explore this concept of what is art and how can art in itself effect change, I would like to explore the works of two internet artists who were the leading pioneers of web-based art, Joan Heemskerk (born 1968 in Kaatsheuvel, Netherlands) and Dirk Paesmans (born 1965 in Brussels, Belgium). The pair created an art duo in 1994 called JODI, along with a website in 1995 under the same name comprising a collection of their digital art, which can be visited through the url \u201Chttp://wwwwwwwww.jodi.org/\u201D.[3][6][10]"}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"JODI is one of the earliest internet artworks ever created, and was one of the founders of the medium. The artistic duo produce video and new media works that play with the increasing presence of technology in our daily lives. According to Artsy.net JODI disrupts and disassembles ubiquitous software, video games, and popular internet platforms such as Google Maps and Twitter, cultivating coding malfunctions and programming glitches [4]. The pair got the idea for the website from code modifications and glitches that were implemented or found by the pair in old video games like Wolfenstein, Quake and Max Payne 2. [3]"}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"The page is composed of various intricate landscapes made in basic HTML. The website shares the appearance of most pre 2000 viruses and upon my first visit to the website I believed I myself had encountered a computer virus rather than a digital artwork. However, that is all this website is, a series of non-functional, non-threatening, visually stimulating works of digital art created through HTML. The artworks are interactable to some degree, many you can scroll through and move around, and there are various 'click points'/ 'hyperlinks' set up in each artwork that will take you to another artwork or page when clicked on. I found the artwork to be very appealing visually as it appeals to my taste in retro 90's fashion, through its use of the generic RGB (Red, Green, Blue) colour scheme, and its 'hacker' style of presentation that reminds me of a command terminal."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"JODI was the winner of the 1999 Webby Awards in the category of Net Art. A tradition of the Webby awards is that every winner of the Webby awards is granted a \u201C5-word acceptance speech\u201D and the creators of JODI chose \u201CUgly Commercial Sons of Bitches\u201D.[3] The intention of the JODI artists in this statement were to criticise the creators of the Webby awards who, although, promote and help advertise the art and net art community, aid in detracting from the value of the artwork. The artists said of JODI \u201CWe decided to put the work immediately on the screen, without our press releases and without our bio. We don't use our site to present information. We present screens and things that are happening in these screens. We avoid explanations. Look at any exhibition: People are sniffing on the information plates next to the art works, before they look at the work itself. They want to know who did a piece, before they have an opinion about it. As long as we can we try to avoid that.\u201D[5] The creators of JODI created the work of art with intention. There is meaning behind their craft and that is what they want to highlight more than anything else. The creators were not looking for fame or fortune in their creation, they created it as art for the sake of art, to deliver a message. Walter Benjamin claims in his book The work of art in the age of mechanical reproduction that \u201Cworks of art are received and valued on different planes. Two types stand out; with one, the accent is on the cult value; with the other, on the exhibition value of the work.\u201D[9] The artwork was not created for exhibition as it had no physical medium, it was a one on one experience with the user and their computer. The artwork's value was entirely based on its cult value. JODI's intention is to expose the backside of the internet, the dangers of it, the beauty of it, the way it works and all the hidden elements it contains. One can think of the artwork as a metaphor of the World Wide Web (WWW). The work highlights that code is behind everything on the web."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"When creating the website the artists made a very simple mistake of forgetting a forward slash in the first command. Due to this, the drawing on the page was broken, incorrectly spaced and all over the place. [6] At first the developers thought there was something wrong with their computer but after some trial and error decided that the effect was quite interesting and decided to publish it online. Due to this, the mistake was reproduced endlessly and eventually everyone saw the exact same mistake. By daring to make that mistake, they made the code the subject of the piece.[5] This drew the audience's attention to the source code of that webpage, which when requested to view in one's browser reveals the correct version of the drawing. Many users attempted to figure out what the code written on the source page is. A user from Everything Cyber Wiki analysed the code, a cluster of green text, and found it be an ascii encoding of a schematic for a Hydrogen (atomic) Bomb.[7] Dirk Paesmans and Joan Heemskerk the creators of JODI said \u201CThat hidden layer was a very interesting way to draw attention to the code, which is inevitably behind everything.\u201D [8] When clicking on the green text the user is taken to a new webpage which is a topographical map that includes various names, messages and an IP address with the text \u201CBetalab\u201D above. The same user on Everything Cyber Wiki discovered that Betalab is a research lab in DC and that this IP address, 131.24.167, is the IP address for an air force base in Alabama. Apparently there is no danger behind this information and that it was added to draw controversy to the website.[7]"}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"In a time before pop-up blockers and anti-virus programs, users who visited the website JODI would be spammed with a series of pop-up windows that would take a picture of your desktop and manipulate into different variants. If the user attempted to stop it they would just be redirected to a different variant. The software did no real harm to the user's computer and was only implemented to frighten the user. Dirk Paesmans and Joan Heemskerk the creators of JODI said \u201CThere was, however, no real manipulation of the computer at a deeper level. For us, the computer's graphic interface was sufficiently interesting.\u201D \u201CIt was indeed all in the head of the user, because nothing actually went wrong. The work was about the user's relationship with the mouse, the keyboard, and the monitor. It included three pieces of software, three programs, each externally exploring one of those elements.\u201D[8]"}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"The intentions of the developers of JODI were to explore the various sides of the internet through artworks of software, code and digital graphics. What I find most interesting about the artwork is the variations that stemmed as a result of its creation. Many users on the internet saw this website as a brilliant opportunity to create replicas that would actually infect your computer with viruses. By hiding themselves under the ploy of this artwork hundreds of false sights were created under similar domains as the original JODI, to the point where even today if you only search \u201Cjoid.org\u201D in your browser you will come across a seemingly endless series of websites that all look the same but not identical to the original artwork. Most of the time you are sent to the original site, and other times you are sent to later works of the artists, but it is an endless expanse of artwork and glitches for one to explore if they are brave enough."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"Walter Benjamin said in his book The work of art in the age of mechanical reproduction \u201CIn principle, a work of art has always been reproducible. Man-made artefacts could always be imitated by men. Replicas were made by pupils in practice of their craft, by masters for diffusing their works, and, finally, by third parties in the pursuit of gain. Mechanical reproduction of a work of art, however, represents something new.\u201D JODI is a website that has reproduced many replicas and in some ways due to its creation created a whole new medium of art, net art. The artists were experimenting with the creation of a mass medium \u201CIn that sense, we are producing a work that pins the honest expression of all these people against our ideas about art. It is the age-old story of the artist who is jealous of the nonartist, because he or she can formulate his or her expressions in a very direct way.\u201D[8]"}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"Art's value is discerned from its authenticity, replicas hold little to no value in the world of art. This is what made the world of net art so controversial. One could copy a website or a piece of net art to a degree of indiscernible inditcality. The only thing that one had power over was a domain and an IP address which could link the authenticity of a website, however, this was still not entirely safe. Most art holds value in authenticity because \u201Cthis unique existence of the work of art determined the history to which it was subject throughout the time of its existence. This includes the changes which it may have suffered in physical condition over the years as well as the various changes in its ownership.\u201D[9] JODI does not degrade in time nor does it suffer damage from the weather and wear. The artwork remains intact throughout its entire life and is even editable, meaning it can be improved. So where does the value in JODI lie?"}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"The developers of JODI said \u201CWell, if I look at our work retrospectively, the basic idea might be to get a better insight into the ways a computer system functions, or rather, how you can tell stories through all kinds of symbolic tricks. Through manipulation, you can discover how the machine is constructed; how it is trying to have you believe that something cannot be done differently. We show that it can certainly be done differently!\u201D[8] So JODI is an expression of how things can be done differently. It is a statement that we can express things in any way we choose, the fact that it was an entirely new medium for that time is proof of, the creators wanted to do things differently."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"Walter Benjamin states that \u201CThe authenticity of a thing is the essence of all that is transmissible from its beginning, ranging from its substantive duration to its testimony to the history which it has experienced. Since the historical testimony rests on the authenticity, the former, too, is jeopardised by reproduction when substantive duration ceases to matter. And what is really jeopardised when the historical testimony is affected is the authority of the object.\u201D[9] so if this authenticity of a thing is jeopardised by its historical authenticity how has JODI managed to maintain its authenticity? The website has had to switch its domain on various occasions, hence the series of www\u2019s in the URL. However, it has maintained its authenticity through its uniqueness. The fact that it is the original website when you find it, gives its value. The fact that so many replicas exist do not detract from the value of the original website. The others are all works of art in their own right, even if they do have malicious intentions."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"The value of the website stands on its own, on its domain. This is entirely new for the world of art as previous replicas of art held little value, however now they stand entirely on their own as individual works to be experienced and appreciated. The beauty of the artwork is that it is not limited by a physical domain, you don't have to go to a museum to see the original, all you need is a computer with an internet connection. Walter Benjamin speaks on the value of replicas and artworks with regard to their authenticity and says that \u201Csecondly, technical reproduction can put the copy of the original into situations which would be out of reach for the original itself. Above all, it enables the original to meet the beholder halfway.\u201D[9] So with JODI there is no need to meet halfway, one can experience the original anywhere as long as they have the technological means. This introduced an entirely new element to the world of art, it brought art to the audience."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"I believe that JODI is a perfect example of art in the digital age and sufficiently allows us to explore the medium of art and what it is. Art is an experience that the viewer has with a creation. The audience experiences its message, its history and its value whether that be cultural, historical, political or monetary, all art holds value and it is there to be experienced. This is what makes art, art."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("h3",{children:"References:"}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"[1] Plato.stanford.edu. 2007. The Definition of Art (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy). [online] Available at: \"https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/art-definition/\" [Accessed 12 April 2022]."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"[2] Brennan, A., 2019. 10 paintings that changed the world. [online] Evening Standard. Available at: \"https://www.standard.co.uk/culture/ten-paintings-that-changed-the-world-a3817526.html\" [Accessed 12 April 2022]."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"[3] En.wikipedia.org. 2021. Jodi (art collective) - Wikipedia. [online] Available at: \"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jodi_(art_collective)\" [Accessed 12 April 2022]."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"[4]Artsy.net. 2022. JODI - 3 Artworks, Bio and Shows on Artsy. [online] Available at: \"https://www.artsy.net/artist/jodi\" [Accessed 12 April 2022]."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"[5]Baumg\xE4rtel, T., 1997. Interview with Jodi. [online] heise online. Available at: \"https://www.heise.de/tp/features/Interview-with-Jodi-3446080.html\" [Accessed 12 April 2022]."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"[6] Digitalcanon.nl. n.d. JODI (Joan Heemskerk and Dirk Paesmans) - DIGITAL ART (1960-2000). [online] Available at: \"https://www.digitalcanon.nl/?artworks=jodi-joan-heemskerk-dirk-paesmans#list\" [Accessed 12 April 2022]."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"[7] Everything cyber Wiki. 2022. Wwwwwwww.jodi.org. [online] Available at: \"https://everythingcyber.fandom.com/wiki/Wwwwwwww.jodi.org\" [Accessed 12 April 2022]."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"[8] Niels Van Tomme, \u201CFrom Readymade to Readybought: An Ongoing History of Computer Art, JODI in conversation with Niels Van Tomme.\u201D Art Papers Magazine, vol. 35, no. 1, Jan/Feb 2011."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"[9] Walter Benjamin (1968). Hannah Arendt (ed.). \"The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction,\" Illuminations. London: Fontana."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("p",{children:"[10]Paesmans, D. and Heemskerk, J., 1995. JODI. [online] wwwwwwjodi.org. Available at: \"http://wwwwwwwww.jodi.org/\" [Accessed 12 April 2022]."}),/*#__PURE__*/_jsx("br",{})]});}

sourcesContent:
import React from 'react' import "./singleBlog1.css" export default function Blog4() { return (

A critical analysis of the internet artwork JODI and its relevance in the world of digital art



What is art? Art and what exactly it is has always been quite a controversial topic in history and contemporary philosophy. Even the idea of whether art can be defined is itself a rather controversial topic. According to the Oxford Dictionary, art is the expression or application of human creative skill and imagination, typically in a visual form such as painting or sculpture, producing works to be appreciated primarily for their beauty or emotional power [1]. Art was always constrained to the mediums of pen, paper and the physical environment and so its definitions were formed to those constraints. Today we live in a digital world, with digital constraints and because of that I believe we need to redefine art, move it away from a standard of beauty, authenticity and audience. The constraints of art in a digital age are dissolved, the definition is far more fluid and needs to be examined in further detail.



The French artist Edgar Degas says “Art is not what you see, but what you make others see.” I believe this quote quite accurately sums up all great art, or at least the purpose of all great artworks, regardless of their medium. Art has the power to influence, and with this power it can sometimes affect real change. An example of this is Leonardo Da Vinci's studies of the foetus in the womb. Da Vinci's discoveries and methods went on to change the way that both artists and scientists studied the human body [2]. In order to explore this concept of what is art and how can art in itself effect change, I would like to explore the works of two internet artists who were the leading pioneers of web-based art, Joan Heemskerk (born 1968 in Kaatsheuvel, Netherlands) and Dirk Paesmans (born 1965 in Brussels, Belgium). The pair created an art duo in 1994 called JODI, along with a website in 1995 under the same name comprising a collection of their digital art, which can be visited through the url “http://wwwwwwwww.jodi.org/”.[3][6][10]



JODI is one of the earliest internet artworks ever created, and was one of the founders of the medium. The artistic duo produce video and new media works that play with the increasing presence of technology in our daily lives. According to Artsy.net JODI disrupts and disassembles ubiquitous software, video games, and popular internet platforms such as Google Maps and Twitter, cultivating coding malfunctions and programming glitches [4]. The pair got the idea for the website from code modifications and glitches that were implemented or found by the pair in old video games like Wolfenstein, Quake and Max Payne 2. [3]



The page is composed of various intricate landscapes made in basic HTML. The website shares the appearance of most pre 2000 viruses and upon my first visit to the website I believed I myself had encountered a computer virus rather than a digital artwork. However, that is all this website is, a series of non-functional, non-threatening, visually stimulating works of digital art created through HTML. The artworks are interactable to some degree, many you can scroll through and move around, and there are various 'click points'/ 'hyperlinks' set up in each artwork that will take you to another artwork or page when clicked on. I found the artwork to be very appealing visually as it appeals to my taste in retro 90's fashion, through its use of the generic RGB (Red, Green, Blue) colour scheme, and its 'hacker' style of presentation that reminds me of a command terminal.



JODI was the winner of the 1999 Webby Awards in the category of Net Art. A tradition of the Webby awards is that every winner of the Webby awards is granted a “5-word acceptance speech” and the creators of JODI chose “Ugly Commercial Sons of Bitches”.[3] The intention of the JODI artists in this statement were to criticise the creators of the Webby awards who, although, promote and help advertise the art and net art community, aid in detracting from the value of the artwork. The artists said of JODI “We decided to put the work immediately on the screen, without our press releases and without our bio. We don't use our site to present information. We present screens and things that are happening in these screens. We avoid explanations. Look at any exhibition: People are sniffing on the information plates next to the art works, before they look at the work itself. They want to know who did a piece, before they have an opinion about it. As long as we can we try to avoid that.”[5] The creators of JODI created the work of art with intention. There is meaning behind their craft and that is what they want to highlight more than anything else. The creators were not looking for fame or fortune in their creation, they created it as art for the sake of art, to deliver a message. Walter Benjamin claims in his book The work of art in the age of mechanical reproduction that “works of art are received and valued on different planes. Two types stand out; with one, the accent is on the cult value; with the other, on the exhibition value of the work.”[9] The artwork was not created for exhibition as it had no physical medium, it was a one on one experience with the user and their computer. The artwork's value was entirely based on its cult value. JODI's intention is to expose the backside of the internet, the dangers of it, the beauty of it, the way it works and all the hidden elements it contains. One can think of the artwork as a metaphor of the World Wide Web (WWW). The work highlights that code is behind everything on the web.



When creating the website the artists made a very simple mistake of forgetting a forward slash in the first command. Due to this, the drawing on the page was broken, incorrectly spaced and all over the place. [6] At first the developers thought there was something wrong with their computer but after some trial and error decided that the effect was quite interesting and decided to publish it online. Due to this, the mistake was reproduced endlessly and eventually everyone saw the exact same mistake. By daring to make that mistake, they made the code the subject of the piece.[5] This drew the audience's attention to the source code of that webpage, which when requested to view in one's browser reveals the correct version of the drawing. Many users attempted to figure out what the code written on the source page is. A user from Everything Cyber Wiki analysed the code, a cluster of green text, and found it be an ascii encoding of a schematic for a Hydrogen (atomic) Bomb.[7] Dirk Paesmans and Joan Heemskerk the creators of JODI said “That hidden layer was a very interesting way to draw attention to the code, which is inevitably behind everything.” [8] When clicking on the green text the user is taken to a new webpage which is a topographical map that includes various names, messages and an IP address with the text “Betalab” above. The same user on Everything Cyber Wiki discovered that Betalab is a research lab in DC and that this IP address, 131.24.167, is the IP address for an air force base in Alabama. Apparently there is no danger behind this information and that it was added to draw controversy to the website.[7]



In a time before pop-up blockers and anti-virus programs, users who visited the website JODI would be spammed with a series of pop-up windows that would take a picture of your desktop and manipulate into different variants. If the user attempted to stop it they would just be redirected to a different variant. The software did no real harm to the user's computer and was only implemented to frighten the user. Dirk Paesmans and Joan Heemskerk the creators of JODI said “There was, however, no real manipulation of the computer at a deeper level. For us, the computer's graphic interface was sufficiently interesting.” “It was indeed all in the head of the user, because nothing actually went wrong. The work was about the user's relationship with the mouse, the keyboard, and the monitor. It included three pieces of software, three programs, each externally exploring one of those elements.”[8]



The intentions of the developers of JODI were to explore the various sides of the internet through artworks of software, code and digital graphics. What I find most interesting about the artwork is the variations that stemmed as a result of its creation. Many users on the internet saw this website as a brilliant opportunity to create replicas that would actually infect your computer with viruses. By hiding themselves under the ploy of this artwork hundreds of false sights were created under similar domains as the original JODI, to the point where even today if you only search “joid.org” in your browser you will come across a seemingly endless series of websites that all look the same but not identical to the original artwork. Most of the time you are sent to the original site, and other times you are sent to later works of the artists, but it is an endless expanse of artwork and glitches for one to explore if they are brave enough.



Walter Benjamin said in his book The work of art in the age of mechanical reproduction “In principle, a work of art has always been reproducible. Man-made artefacts could always be imitated by men. Replicas were made by pupils in practice of their craft, by masters for diffusing their works, and, finally, by third parties in the pursuit of gain. Mechanical reproduction of a work of art, however, represents something new.” JODI is a website that has reproduced many replicas and in some ways due to its creation created a whole new medium of art, net art. The artists were experimenting with the creation of a mass medium “In that sense, we are producing a work that pins the honest expression of all these people against our ideas about art. It is the age-old story of the artist who is jealous of the nonartist, because he or she can formulate his or her expressions in a very direct way.”[8]



Art's value is discerned from its authenticity, replicas hold little to no value in the world of art. This is what made the world of net art so controversial. One could copy a website or a piece of net art to a degree of indiscernible inditcality. The only thing that one had power over was a domain and an IP address which could link the authenticity of a website, however, this was still not entirely safe. Most art holds value in authenticity because “this unique existence of the work of art determined the history to which it was subject throughout the time of its existence. This includes the changes which it may have suffered in physical condition over the years as well as the various changes in its ownership.”[9] JODI does not degrade in time nor does it suffer damage from the weather and wear. The artwork remains intact throughout its entire life and is even editable, meaning it can be improved. So where does the value in JODI lie?



The developers of JODI said “Well, if I look at our work retrospectively, the basic idea might be to get a better insight into the ways a computer system functions, or rather, how you can tell stories through all kinds of symbolic tricks. Through manipulation, you can discover how the machine is constructed; how it is trying to have you believe that something cannot be done differently. We show that it can certainly be done differently!”[8] So JODI is an expression of how things can be done differently. It is a statement that we can express things in any way we choose, the fact that it was an entirely new medium for that time is proof of, the creators wanted to do things differently.



Walter Benjamin states that “The authenticity of a thing is the essence of all that is transmissible from its beginning, ranging from its substantive duration to its testimony to the history which it has experienced. Since the historical testimony rests on the authenticity, the former, too, is jeopardised by reproduction when substantive duration ceases to matter. And what is really jeopardised when the historical testimony is affected is the authority of the object.”[9] so if this authenticity of a thing is jeopardised by its historical authenticity how has JODI managed to maintain its authenticity? The website has had to switch its domain on various occasions, hence the series of www’s in the URL. However, it has maintained its authenticity through its uniqueness. The fact that it is the original website when you find it, gives its value. The fact that so many replicas exist do not detract from the value of the original website. The others are all works of art in their own right, even if they do have malicious intentions.



The value of the website stands on its own, on its domain. This is entirely new for the world of art as previous replicas of art held little value, however now they stand entirely on their own as individual works to be experienced and appreciated. The beauty of the artwork is that it is not limited by a physical domain, you don't have to go to a museum to see the original, all you need is a computer with an internet connection. Walter Benjamin speaks on the value of replicas and artworks with regard to their authenticity and says that “secondly, technical reproduction can put the copy of the original into situations which would be out of reach for the original itself. Above all, it enables the original to meet the beholder halfway.”[9] So with JODI there is no need to meet halfway, one can experience the original anywhere as long as they have the technological means. This introduced an entirely new element to the world of art, it brought art to the audience.



I believe that JODI is a perfect example of art in the digital age and sufficiently allows us to explore the medium of art and what it is. Art is an experience that the viewer has with a creation. The audience experiences its message, its history and its value whether that be cultural, historical, political or monetary, all art holds value and it is there to be experienced. This is what makes art, art.



References:



[1] Plato.stanford.edu. 2007. The Definition of Art (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy). [online] Available at: "https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/art-definition/" [Accessed 12 April 2022].

[2] Brennan, A., 2019. 10 paintings that changed the world. [online] Evening Standard. Available at: "https://www.standard.co.uk/culture/ten-paintings-that-changed-the-world-a3817526.html" [Accessed 12 April 2022].

[3] En.wikipedia.org. 2021. Jodi (art collective) - Wikipedia. [online] Available at: "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jodi_(art_collective)" [Accessed 12 April 2022].
